Award.AwardTitle: CNIC: US-Australia Planning Visits for UNC-NCSU-Queensland Partnership on Novel Materials and Devices for Transdermal Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CNIC program, Dr. Tarl Prow (Deputy Director, Dermatology Research Center, University of Queensland) and the PI propose an innovative mechanism for minimally invasive and in situ detection of melanoma progression using novel microscale devices that contain microneedles as well as microarrays, which detect chemical processes specific to melanoma. Three graduate research assistants (US citizens or US permanent residents) will travel to Dr. Prow's laboratory for four month periods to perform the following tasks: (1) synthesis of microneedle devices for transdermal detection of melanoma, (2) microneedle-skin characterization and mechanical characterization, and (3) studies to assess the functionality of microneedle-microarray devices for detection of melanoma.

The goal of the proposed effort is to catalyze new international collaborations between the PI and Dr. Prow, who are uniquely qualified to achieve the program goals. Dr. Prow's lab has pioneered efforts involving microneedle-based detection of melanoma. The PI?s lab has pioneered research efforts involving rapid prototyping of microneedles for transdermal drug delivery and sensing. The project will contrbute to improved melanoma treatment by enabling small samples to be repeatedly obtained from single lesions over time, thus allowing molecular mechanisms involved in melanomagenesis to be better understood. The PI is leading a series of lectures and scientific demonstrations in Raleigh for young people in the broader community; these "Science Saturday" events take place at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. The PI and students will incorporate results and demonstration materials from the project in these events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NCSU PhD student visited Prof. Tim Woodfield's laboratory at the University of Otago (Christchurch, New Zealand), Dr. Roman Kostecki's and Prof. Heike Ebendorff-Heidepriem's at the University of Adelaide (Adealide, Australia), as well as Prof. Tarl Prow's at the University of South Australia (Adelaide, Australia) between October 2018 and March 2019.

In the study with Prof. Woodfield's group, gelatin was reacted with allyl glycidyl ether (AGE) to create allylated gelatin (GelAGE). Mr. Yang studied polymerization of GelAGE with ultraviolet (Irgacure® 2959) and visible light (LAP, Ru/SPS) photoinitiators for potential use in lithography-based and extrusion-based 3D printing. GelAGE with LAP initiated polymerization was shown to be a useful thiol-ene clickable bioink formulation. GelAGE with Ru/SPS initiated polymerization was shown to provide a wide range of stiffness and seamless mechanical gradients by pausing processing for a short term or replenishing SPS. The viscosity of these materials can be adjusted by modifying the DTT concentration. These results support the use of visible light photoinitiators such as LAP and Ru/SPS rather than ultraviolet photoinitiators such as Irgacure® 2959.  

In one study with Prof. Ebendorff-Heidepriem’s group, 3D-printed micro-needle technology was combined with an optical fiber tip sensor to create an optical fiber-based in vivo biosensor to detect reversible protein carbonylation.  In vivo measurements of protein carbonylation were obtained from pig skin, an anesthetized live mouse, and a wheat plant.  

In another study with Prof. Ebendorff-Heidepriem’s group, 3D-printed micro-needle technology was combined with an optical fiber tip sensor to create a reactive oxygen species sensor for understanding redox balance in pigskin, live mouse, and wheat plant.  In vivo measurements of protein carbonylation were obtained from pig skin, an anesthetized live mouse, and a wheat plant.  

This collaboration between Australia- and New Zealand-based researchers and Dr. Narayan (North Carolina State University) and his students is enabling better understanding of innovative devices for minimally invasive and in situ detection of medical conditions.

Dr. Narayan's experience in interfacing with colleagues at the University of Queensland, the University of South Australia, the University of Adelaide, and the University of Otago will make him a resource at North Carolina State University for future interactions with these institutions and with other Australasian universities.

 


Last Modified: 07/07/2019
Modified by: Roger J Narayan
